instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.P5VS4RS3_EN: What is P5VS4RS3_EN? PP5VS4RS3_EN is a signal that enables the PP5V_S4RS3 power rail. When you see _EN in front of a signal name, it means that it is enabling whatever comes before the _EN when the signal is high..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.S5_PWR_EN: What is S5_PWR_EN? S5_PWR_EN is a signal that turns on all S5 power rails when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message:
Working on this board that according to client died after he dropped the computer. Already swapped <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> but no dice. Board has no signs of water damage.

Edit 1:

Managed to get pp3v42 stabilized to 0.9v after replacing a cap right before <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>. Then replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and the voltage raised to 1.2v.

Edit 2:

I decided injecting 3.42v after the g3hot supply inductor, but the current draw is too low to be a short to ground (0.09a). Maybe the <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> i put in was bad too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message: Do you have green/orange light??? <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> present?? PPBUS G3H present and what voltage is there?? Also if it was dropped there is a big chance it have broken traces and could be a no fix.... Anyway lets measure first and see what wwe found...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message: No light on charger but <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is preset and now i'm only getting 1.2v. My guess now is that the buck converter LT3470AED is bad, as it was removed from a donor board.

threads.message: Swapped <CHIP>U7090</CHIP>, getting 3,42v at <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>. Moving on to check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal.

threads.message: ACOK, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL> and PPBUS?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> missing, haswell processor. Going to check all the input signals to see if some is missing. But as was a drop that caused the failure, i'm already considering a crack solder ball under the processor.

threads.message: Got myself into a loophole now. Can't get the <SIGNAL>P5VS4RS3_EN</SIGNAL> to get the <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>, all the logic aids powered by this won't be funcional.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message: I suspect corrosion under SMC or dead SMC.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message: I really doubt, this board doesn't show the least sign of corrosion. It failed after a drop, my bet is that there's a crack on one of the processor balls. Anyway, will try reflowing the smc and get back with the resuls. PS: I don't have one of these 980YFE smcs here, just the other type.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message:
PPBUS should be 12.6V and there should be a green light. Without a green light the machine will never turn on. SMC is specific to each type of board, if you replace the SMC you need to take one from an identical donor board.

Also check voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 24426"]PPBUS should be 12.6V and there should be a green light. Without a green light the machine will never turn on. SMC is specific to each type of board, if you replace the SMC you need to take one from an identical donor board.

Also check voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>[/QUOTE]

I can't use another same chip SMC really? Didn't know that it must be from same model board. I thought if it was the same chip it can be used, even saw Louis saying on a video that he used to buy chips with balls from ebay... Are you sure about that? I know SPI rom chips may have some problems with ME region, but SMC I really don't think so.

So to the measurements: <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> is 64mv and <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL> is 3,35v. And also PPBUS is 12,33v. Remember Louis saying on a video that a bad SMC causes a drop on PPBUS voltage. Are we getting close here. As the failure was caused by a drop, will try reflowing the smc and get back with the results.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no light on charger, <CHIP>U7900</CHIP> power cycling
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> should en 3,3 volt if I am correct 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12,33 is to low! Reball or replace SMC then check again

threads.message: Did you disconnect the keyboard? <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL> is being pulled down by something.
